prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Mapping of the HCN emmission and assesment of CO production
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This setup aims at mapping the gaseous emission to asses the outgassing pattern from the spatial mapping and line shape (velocity field). In the lower side band CO and CS emission will be quantified to measure the molecular abundances of these molecules.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Sensitivity: On the basis of the ESA scenario for medium activity of comet 67P (stating H2O and CO production rates) and abundances (for HCN, CS and CH3OH) that we have measured in tens of comets, we estimate that the HCN(4-3) line intensity will vary from 20 to 60 mJykm/s per beam for a semi compact configuration C34-2, during the period we ask to observe the comet.
Imaging and flux losses: Since comets are neither point source nor extended ones (the column density decreases as the inverse of the distance to the center) we have taken into account the losses due to the interferometric technique which eliminates large scale structures. If the available configuration at the time of observations is more compact we expect a larger signal to noise ratio. If it is more extended the data reduction will be optimized using tapering of the long baselines to maxmize the signal-to-noise ratio, especially for the detection of the weaker CO and CS lines.
Correlator setup: The higher spectral resolution is requested for the stronger HCN line which should be on the order of 1 to 1.5km/s wide. Due to lower signal-to-noise expected for the other lines, a spectral resolution of 0.1 km/s will be sufficient.
Scheduling constraints: We also aim at observing the lines over a wide range of periods, starting in April 2015 when the signal-to-noise ratio should be sufficient. We target April (rh=1.8 AU), July (rh=1.3 AU) and october (rh=1.4 AU) periods. We will probe the transition to an activity fully dominated by water sublimation between April and July. We also want to extend to the october time frame as the comet did show asymetry in activity with respect to perihelion in the past and this needs to be related to seasonal effects and likely different sides of the nucleus being active pre (April) versus post-perihelion (October).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Coma temperature and methanol production
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This setup aims at observing simultaneously four of the strongest lines of methanol in the submm range that would enable us to estimate the gas temperature of the coma of comet 67P. In addition another CS line is covered by this setup.

prj:TemporalParameters.prj:note: Scheduling this setup as close in time as possible to the other one is desirable to derive the HCN/CH3OH abundance ratio and use the temperature derived from the observations of CH3OH to accurately infer the production rate of HCN and CO.

Scheduling this setup as close in time as possible to the other one is desirable to derive the HCN/CH3OH abundance ratio and use the temperature derived from the observations of CH3OH to accurately infer the production rate of HCN and CO.

Scheduling this setup as close in time as possible to the other one is desirable to derive the HCN/CH3OH abundance ratio and use the temperature derived from the observations of CH3OH to accurately infer the production rate of HCN and CO.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Sensitivity: This setup targets primarily the Methanol lines that are best suited both for estimating the gas temperature of the coma of comet 67P at the ALMA spatial resolution and the production rate of that molecule. We have determined both theoretically and from the experience of observing these lines at CSO and IRAM-30m that they are the strongest in the 3mm to 0.6mm range and also correctly probe the gas temperature in a cometary atmosphere as their rotational temperature is close to the physical temperature of the gas in the colision dominated zone. The estimated intensities range from 8--11 mJykm/s in April to 17--26 mJykm/s in October in the semi compact configuration C34-2. The required sensitivity (2.3 mJykm/s rms) should enable the detection of the lines at each three epochs.
Imaging and flux losses: Due to the peculiar column density profile of cometary atmosphere, more compact configuration will increase the signal-to-noise while in case of more extended configuration we will reduce the data using tapering of the long baselines to maxmize the signal-to-noise ratio.
Correlator setup: The line width should be the same as for HCN and a spectral resolution of 0.1km/s is sufficient for these lines.
Scheduling constraints: Same as for the other setup, but executing the two setups as close as possible in time for each period is desirable to avoid being affected by time variation of the source in between.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The Rosetta mission will explore in situ (at a distance of 5 to 200km) comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko, nominally from July 2014 to December 2015. Comet 67P will reach perihelion on 12 August 2015, during the ALMA Cycle 2 period. On the basis of the ESA adopted activity level of the comet, the main molecular species should be detectable with ALMA during the high activity phase of the comet from April to October 2015. We propose to observe at three different epochs, pre and post-perihelion the key species HCN, CH3OH and CO to derive their total production rates, the gas temperature, their spatial and velocity distribution on the resolution scale (500-1500km) accessible with ALMA. At the same time Rosetta and especially the MIRO and VIRTIS experiments will be observing the same species in situ. As Co-Is of these Rosetta experiments we will have the opportunity to establish a ground truth for the outgassing activity that has been observed over two decades in over 40 comets. We will connect the measurement obtained on the ~1000 km scale from Earth with the activity observed and quantified in situ (from the nucleus surface to beyond 100km) by Rosetta experiments.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: This proposal is related to 2013.1.01137.S (PI Paganini), which is also related to Rosetta. Our proposal concentrates on a combined analysis with data from Rosetta instruments, to provide a unique multi-scale view of the comet, in order to understand the interactions within the inner coma. The epochs at which the two proposals require observations are different, and the data collected by both would be complementary.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: IRAM Grenoble, Institute of Millimetric Radioastronomy (IRAM)
